headline: Intel cuts back spending, workforce as struggling chip maker mounts comeback
summary: Intel Corp. is shedding thousands of workers and cutting expenses as its new CEO works to revive the fortunes of the struggling chipmaker that helped launch Silicon Valley but has fallen behind rivals like Nvidia Corp. and Advanced Micro Devices Inc.  In a memo to employees Thursday, CEO Lip-Bu Tan said Intel plans to end the year with 75,000 “core” workers excluding subsidiaries, through layoffs and attrition.  In addition, Intel will scrap previously planned projects in Germany and Poland and also move assembly and test operations in Costa Rica to larger sites in Vietnam and Malaysia.

raw.headline: Intel cuts back spending, workforce as struggling chip maker mounts comeback

In a memo to employees Thursday, CEO Lip-Bu Tan said Intel plans to end the year with 75,000 “core” workers excluding subsidiaries, through layoffs and attrition.  In addition, Intel will scrap previously planned projects in Germany and Poland and also move assembly and test operations in Costa Rica to larger sites in Vietnam and Malaysia.

headline: Intel is cutting more jobs as CEO Tan tries to fix manufacturing missteps
summary: (Reuters) -Intel is going to end the year with a workforce that is over a fifth smaller than last year, it said on Thursday, and new CEO Lip Bu Tan presented a blueprint for a more cost-disciplined, streamlined chipmaker that would issue "no more blank checks."  The job cuts - a majority of which have been completed already - are part of an effort by Tan since he took the helm in March to turn around the storied U.S. chipmaker.  Intel has divested businesses, laid off employees and redirected resources.

The job cuts - a majority of which have been completed already - are part of an effort by Tan since he took the helm in March to turn around the storied U.S. chipmaker.  Intel has divested businesses, laid off employees and redirected resources.

summary: Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) experienced a notable 68% price increase over the past quarter, a surge partly attributed to its strategic collaboration with Aligned and USC ISI to develop the MEGALODON large language model. headline: Aligned Joins Forces with AMD and USC ISI to Power Next-Generation AI with MEGALODON Language Model
summary: Aligned, a leading innovator in AI infrastructure and scalable machine learning solutions, today announced a strategic collaboration with AMD and the University of Southern California's Information Sciences Institute (USC ISI) to accelerate the development and training of MEGALODON, a cutting-edge large language model (LLM). The collaboration centers on harnessing the powerful AMD Instinct™ MI300 GPUs and Aligned's expertise in AI operations to train the model efficiently on non-NVIDIA architect

headline: Intel beats shareholder lawsuit over $32 billion stock plunge
summary: (Reuters) -A federal judge dismissed a lawsuit accusing Intel of defrauding shareholders by concealing problems in a business where it manufactured chips for outside customers, leading to a $32 billion one-day plunge in its market value.  While saying she "understands plaintiffs' frustrations," U.S. District Judge Trina Thompson in San Francisco ruled on Wednesday that Intel did not wait too long to reveal a $7 billion fiscal 2023 operating loss in its foundry business.  Intel's stock price sank 26% last August 2, one day after the chipmaker announced more than 15,000 layoffs and suspended its dividend, hoping to save $10 billion in 2025.

raw.headline: Intel beats shareholder lawsuit over $32 billion stock plunge

Intel's stock price sank 26% last August 2, one day after the chipmaker announced more than 15,000 layoffs and suspended its dividend, hoping to save $10 billion in 2025.

headline: Should You Buy Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) Stock Before Aug. 5?

The semiconductor industry is at the heart of the artificial intelligence (AI) revolution.

headline: Trump administration recommends location verification for AI chips
summary: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) -U.S. President Donald Trump's administration on Wednesday recommended implementing export controls that would verify the location of advanced artificial intelligence chips, a move that was applauded by U.S. lawmakers from both parties in both houses of Congress.  The recommendation was part of a broader AI blueprint released on Wednesday that aimed to boost exports of AI hardware and software to U.S. allies and relax U.S. environmental rules to speed the construction of new AI data centers.  It added the U.S. government should "explore leveraging new and existing location verification features on advanced AI compute to ensure that the chips are not in countries of concern."

It added the U.S. government should "explore leveraging new and existing location verification features on advanced AI compute to ensure that the chips are not in countries of concern."
